results.title: 42 Up
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “World in action”.
In 1964 a team from Granada Television set out to test the following theory - are children’s lives already mapped out for them by the age of seven? This was the start of a remarkable series which documents groups of children from childhood through puberty to adulthood. Of the original 14 subjects, 11 remain. Now halfway through their lives, how close are they to realising their dreams and ambitions? This enthralling film also starts asking grander questions common to all humans - what is love, what is character, what is success?

results.title: 7.30 Report: The Dismissal
results.brief_description:
On the eve of the thirtieth anniversary of the dismissal of the Whitlam government, a special edition of the ABC’s national nightly current affairs program, ‘7:30 Report’ takes an in-depth look at the events of 1975.

The program features interviews with both Gough Whitlam and Malcolm Fraser who comment on the events of 1975, discuss the possibility of 4 year fixed terms for both the House of Representatives and the Senate and reflect upon the politics of modern Australia, and upon each other.

Broadcast on 10th November, 2005.

results.title: A Bill of divorcement. Ruby Gentry
results.creator_credit: King Vidor, George Cukor, Joseph Bernhard, David O. Selznick, Bernhard-Vidor Productions and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: A Bill of divorcement: Katharine Hepburn’s debut in what was to be the first film in a long association with director George Cukor. Hillary Fairfield (John Barrymore), shellshocked during World War One, escapes from the asylum on the day his ex-wife is to remarry. Unable to adjust, he must also confront his now grown-up daughter Sydney (katharine Hepburn). Facing reality, he finally accepts his wife’s determination to marry a sane, healthy man, but does not know of the impending sacrifice his daughter is to make. Sydney knows that the streak of madness in her father is inherited, not war-induced and, fearful of passing it on to her children, she cancels her marriage in order to care for her father. Cast also includes Billie Burke and David Manners. Ruby Gentry: Jennifer Jones stars as Ruby, a young southern woman from a poor white-trash family determined to improve her lot in life by marrying into wealth even though she is romantically involved with Boake Tackman (Charlton Heston) who too is from the “wrong” side of the tracks. So when successful businessman Jim Gentry (Karl Malden) finds himself totally in love with Ruby and insists on making her his wife, Ruby, of course, cannot resist this fortuitous offer. However, for Gentry it will turn out to be a most unfortunate decision with dire consequences. Cast also includes Tom Tully and James Anderson.

results.title: 21 Up
results.creator_credit: Margaret Bottomley, Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
In 1964, a number of seven year olds expressed their views on life, leisure, love, marriage, colour prejudice, education and money (SEVEN UP). Another program was made about them and their changing attitudes when they were fourteen (7 PLUS SEVEN). Now at twenty-one, using clips from these films, the program compares the responses of this group of individuals as they grow to adulthood. This film is recommended for Years 11-12 and Tertiary level education.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Twenty eight up continues the World in action series, following the development and changing attitudes of a group of British children every seven years, they are now twenty eight. This program talks to Tony, Bruce and Suzi.

results.title: 7 plus seven
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Fourteen children from a variety of school backgrounds, interviewed in 1964 for television about their hopes and aspirations, are followed up seven years later. Extracts from the first program, made when the children were seven years old, are shown and the children comment on any changes in their ideas.

results.title: 7 Days in September
results.creator_credit: Steven Rosenbaum and Broadcast News Networks
results.brief_description: This moving, if rudimentarily filmed documentary, is a collective account of ‘September 11, 2001’ and that day’s impact on a variety of New Yorkers. The filmmakers utilise an array of original footage shot over that week by professionals and by amateurs; they also interview an array of people who lived in New York at the time who describe their own responses and the unusual occurrences witnessed. The narrative focuses on the feel in New York over the week: the mood on the street, impromptu prayer sessions that were conducted, for example, as well as debates that raged between strangers; the clean up effort and the way that people pulled together, helping each other, making donations, giving blood, and providing emotional support. Whilst in no way an analysis of the calamity, the filmmakers eloquently capture the small stories. The work in a minor way, also addresses the role and the dilemma of any documentary filmmaker caught up in a tragedy - to film or not to film and at what stage does observation of a grand-scale catastrophe cross over into exploitation and opportunism.
